description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals& Chemistry Daily Daily-- A new study on Engineering- Thermal Engineering is now available. Funders for this research include U.S. Department of Energy’ s Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy under the Sunshot Initiative Award, U.S. Department of Energy’ s National Nuclear Security...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals &
Chemistry Daily Daily \-- A new study on Engineering - Thermal Engineering is
now available. According to news reporting originating from Atlanta, Georgia,
by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "A two-step cycle was considered
for solar thermochemical energy storage based on aluminum-doped calcium
manganite reduction/oxidation reactions for direct integration into Air
Brayton cycles. The two steps encompassed (1) the storage of concentrated
solar direct irradiation via the thermal reduction of aluminum-doped calcium
manganite and (2) the delivery of heat to an Air-Brayton cycle via re-
oxidation of oxygen-deficient aluminum-doped calcium manganite."

Funders for this research include U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Energy
Efficiency and Renewable Energy under the Sunshot Initiative Award, U.S.
Department of Energy's National Nuclear Security Administration.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the Georgia Institute
of Technology, "The re-oxidized aluminum-doped calcium manganite was fed back
to the first step to complete the cycle. A 5 kW(th) solar thermochemical
reactor operating under vacuum was fabricated and tested to examine the first
cycle reduction step. Reactor operating conditions and high-flux solar
simulator control were tuned for continuous reactor operation with particle
temperatures > 1073 K. Continuous operation was achieved using intermittent,
dense granular flows."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "A maximum absorption
efficiency of 64.7% was demonstrated, accounting for both sensible and
chemical heat storage."

For more information on this research see: Experimental Demonstration of a 5
Kw(Th) Granular-flow Reactor for Solar Thermochemical Energy Storage With
Aluminum-doped Calcium Manganite Particles. _Applied Thermal Engineering_ ,
2020;173():. _Applied Thermal Engineering_ can be contacted at: Pergamon-
Elsevier Science Ltd, The Boulevard, Langford Lane, Kidlington, Oxford OX5
1GB, England. (Elsevier \- [www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com);
Applied Thermal Engineering - <http://www.journals.elsevier.com/applied-
thermal-engineering/>)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting P.G. Loutzenhiser, Georgia Institute of Technology, George Woodruff
School of Mechanical Engineering, Atlanta, GA 30332, United States. Additional
authors for this research include A.J. Schrader, G.L. Schieber and A.
Ambrosini.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.applthermaleng.2020.115257>. This DOI is a link to
an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be
your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Study Results from Georgia Institute of Technology Broaden Understanding of Thermal Engineering [Experimental Demonstration of a 5 Kw(Th) Granular-flow Reactor for Solar Thermochemical Energy Storage With Aluminum-doped Calcium Manganite ...]: Engineering - Thermal Engineering
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals & Chemistry Daily Daily -- A new study on Engineering - Thermal Engineering is now available. According to news reporting originating from Atlanta, Georgia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “A two-step cycle was considered for solar thermochemical energy storage based on aluminum-doped calcium manganite reduction/oxidation reactions for direct integration into Air Brayton cycles. The two steps encompassed (1) the storage of concentrated solar direct irradiation via the thermal reduction of aluminum-doped calcium manganite and (2) the delivery of heat to an Air-Brayton cycle via re-oxidation of oxygen-deficient aluminum-doped calcium manganite.”

Funders for this research include U.S. Department of Energy’s Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy under the Sunshot Initiative Award, U.S. Department of Energy’s National Nuclear Security Administration.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the Georgia Institute of Technology, “The re-oxidized aluminum-doped calcium manganite was fed back to the first step to complete the cycle. A 5 kW(th) solar thermochemical reactor operating under vacuum was fabricated and tested to examine the first cycle reduction step. Reactor operating conditions and high-flux solar simulator control were tuned for continuous reactor operation with particle temperatures > 1073 K. Continuous operation was achieved using intermittent, dense granular flows.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “A maximum absorption efficiency of 64.7% was demonstrated, accounting for both sensible and chemical heat storage.”

For more information on this research see: Experimental Demonstration of a 5 Kw(Th) Granular-flow Reactor for Solar Thermochemical Energy Storage With Aluminum-doped Calcium Manganite Particles. Applied Thermal Engineering, 2020;173():. Applied Thermal Engineering can be contacted at: Pergamon-Elsevier Science Ltd, The Boulevard, Langford Lane, Kidlington, Oxford OX5 1GB, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Applied Thermal Engineering - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/applied-thermal-engineering/)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting P.G. Loutzenhiser, Georgia Institute of Technology, George Woodruff School of Mechanical Engineering, Atlanta, GA 30332, United States. Additional authors for this research include A.J. Schrader, G.L. Schieber and A. Ambrosini.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.applthermaleng.2020.115257. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
